def.p: Is said to have occurred when microorganisms including bacteria, viruses, and some parasites are able to stop an antimicrobial such as antibiotics, antivirals, and antimalarials from effectively working against it when administered.

Constitutes all those infectious diseases that have recently surfaced. They are characterized by a rapid expansion in incidence beyond the population and geographic range of their first emergence and pose serious public health threats to the global population in the near future. They may also be viewed as all those infectious diseases whose incidence has increased within the past 2Â years.
Are caused by pathogenic microorganisms including bacteria, viruses, parasites, or fungi that can spread directly from one person to another.

As suggested by the name, reemerging infectious diseases were once classified or seen as major public health threats to countries and regions, but were eventually contained and substantially reduced, only to resurface in recent times posing similar challenges to public health. Examples include Tuberculosis and Malaria.
Are diseases that are transmitted by vectors. Most commonly, these vectors are bloodsucking insects which ingest disease-producing microorganisms and then inject them into their new host.

Comprise diseases that originate from animals with the potential to be transmitted to humans through viruses, bacteria, parasites, and fungi. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, six out of every ten infectious diseases are zoonotic, and another three out of every four emerging diseases are contracted through animals.
